The Danish director, Per Egeland, announced today that the museum will cancel its opening exhibition “The Selfish Gallery: Abstract Art and the Human Self” next month, in the interests of preserving the institution’s traditional Danish programming and preserving the Danish identity. The exhibition, which was originally scheduled for December 2019, was originally set to open on September 24.When asked about the future of the exhibition, Egeland said: “We must think of the Danish identity as a continuous process and as a complex, evolving organism that depends on the promotion of interests from outside and on the promotion of interests within Danish society. We must also think about how the individual will relate to the whole of the Danish landscape.”The Danish government recently approved a budget of $56 million to mitigate the economic impact of the coronavirus, which has infected more than 25,000 people worldwide. The Museum of Contemporary Art (MoCA) in Los Angeles announced today that it has created four new artist-in-residence positions. The MoCA Artist-in-Residence program is designed to help local artists and small-scale artmakers through a series of support, mentorship, and curation engagements. MoCA’s new roles are:The first position, which is funded by the museum, will be an associate curator at the institution for ten weeks. The curator will be responsible for presenting contemporary art within the Los Angeles area. In addition to conducting explorations of art through the lens of contemporary art, the artist-in-residence will find ways to connect with filmmakers, artists, and other audiences in the greater Los Angeles region.
